content: Yes, sea turtles do have predators while they're underwater, such as sharks, killer whales, and some species of large predatory fish. However, sea turtles have evolved several adaptations to help them evade predators while underwater, including their hard shell, camouflage, and the ability to hold their breath for extended periods. Additionally, sea turtles tend to feed on prey that is too small to be of much interest to larger predators, which helps to reduce their risk of predation while they're submerged. Despite these adaptations, sea turtles are still vulnerable to predation, especially when nesting or as hatchlings emerging from their nests.
